column4: My main drive seems to be assigned to I/O address 0x3F7-0x3F7.  Is there a way to change the I/O address (or better yet make it a range, because 0x3F7 is already in use)?
that should be handled automatically during PCI bus negotiation.  unless you have ancient hardware
If it's being handled automatically, it's being handled automatically wrong
you are talking about what kind of drive interface?  IDE?  SATA?
make sure there are no "hardwired" resource assignments in the BIOS.
My BIOS has no such options.
It only happens with kernel 2.6.18; windows and 2.6.15-23 are fine.
that's odd.  it does rule out the bios.  :)
I'm recompiling 2.6.18 right now with the same I/O scheduler as the 2.6.15-23 kernel.  If it's not that.....
I can't imagine the scheduler having an impact on IO port assignments, but we'll see.
I can't imagine anything else that makes sense either.
Heh, yeah.  Think the architecture it was compiled for would affect anything? :\
I've been making mine for P4 coppermine... I guess if this doesn't work I'll try again with 386
I've never seen a structural dump of FAT
it might be possible.  it's a windows file system, so it's perfectly possible that it's possible to dump it, and I don't know about it.
